newsitem.title: USA: Lost hikers found on Oregon's Mount Hood.
newsitem.headline: Lost hikers found on Oregon's Mount Hood.

text.p: Rescuers on Tuesday found four climbers who had been missing on Oregon's Mount Hood since a blizzard hit the dangerous peak Easter Sunday.
The four climbers, all in their 30s, were found hiking down the mountain near Portland as the blizzard conditions cleared.
"This is the best-case scenario," said Clackamas County Deputy Sheriff Damon Coates.

The climbers, Michael Whelan and Shawn Corrigan of Bend and Colette Whelan Ownes and Robert Sheley of Portland, set out at 5 a.m. Sunday on a planned day hike to the summit, the state's highest peak at 11,245 feet.
The weather was clear and bright, but by 11 a.m. a snowstorm had hit the mountain.
"We had 75 mph winds and blizzard conditions," Coates said. Rescue efforts were interrupted Monday morning because of continued bad weather.
The four, with provisions for about a day, sheltered themselves in a snow cave until conditions improved.
After they were found, rescuers discovered the group's mountain locator unit had malfunctioned.
"They activated it Sunday night, but it was not emitting a signal," Coates said. It was the first time in his 10 years of mountain rescue work that he could remember such a malfunction.
Coates said Mount Hood was entering its most dangerous season, as spring attracts numerous climbers who can be surprised by rapidly changing weather conditions.
So far this year there have been no fatalities on the mountain, although two lost snowboarders recently were found by rescuers in separate incidents.
